unnormalised: So, you burnt the roti again? Blame your genes! Failed that math test? It's the genetics, yaar! Genetics, the scapegoat of the 21st century. But seriously folks, the field of genetics is exploding faster than a pressure cooker on high heat, and it's not just about figuring out if you'll inherit your granddad’s receding hairline.

unnormalised: For centuries, we blamed everything on karma or "bhagwan ki marzi". Now, we have scientific scapegoats – chromosomes, DNA, and those pesky recessive genes. Remember Mendelian genetics from high school? Dominant, recessive, blah blah. Turns out, life's a tad more complicated than just Punnett squares. As Dr. Anuradha Reddy at CMC Vellore told me the other day over chai, (and I quote loosely), "It's a freakin' genetic jungle out there!" I mean, she used slightly more professional language, but you get the gist.

unnormalised: Think about it. Are you a "chai" person or a "coffee" person? Genes might play a role. Do you love cilantro, or does it taste like soap? Genes again! Even your risk of catching COVID-19, or developing a severe case, has a genetic component. I read a study published in "The Lancet" where they claimed some genes had upto 70% impact on severity. Mind-blowing stuff! Although my understanding of genetics is slightly less complicated than understanding the plot of a typical Bollywood movie, I think I can understand the basics.

unnormalised: Genetic testing is all the rage these days. You can spit in a tube, mail it off to some lab in the US (for about $99, or Rs. 8200 these days!) and voila! A few weeks later, you get a report telling you your ancestry, your risk for certain diseases, and if you’re likely to be a morning person. Imagine, you can tell your boss that science prevents you from attending those 8 AM meetings! (Disclaimer: This may not work, and I am not responsible for any job loss).

unnormalised: But here's the thing, knowing you're predisposed to something doesn't mean it's a done deal. Lifestyle still matters. You might have the "sweet tooth" gene, but you can still resist the urge to devour that entire box of "gulab jamun" (Okay, maybe just *most* of the box). And the interpretation of these genetic results is far from straightforward. A genetic counselor like Ms. Priya Kumar from AIIMS Delhi is your best bet to help interpret these reports. They can help you understand what it all *really* means. They have to understand it all, after all. It's their job.

unnormalised: Also, genetics isn’t just about health or ancestry. It's revolutionizing agriculture. Remember Bt cotton? Genetically modified to resist pests. Scientists are working on creating crops that are more drought-resistant, more nutritious, and basically, able to survive whatever Mother Nature throws at them. It's like giving our food a superpower!

unnormalised: So, next time you mess up a recipe, trip on the stairs, or generally just have a bad day, remember, you can always blame your genes. It's the modern Indian solution to avoiding personal responsibility! But more importantly, remember that genetics is a powerful tool that is reshaping our understanding of ourselves and the world around us. It's complex, fascinating, and a little bit scary – kind of like navigating the Delhi Metro during rush hour. Just don't forget that even with the power of genetics, you're still responsible for your actions. Try not to blame it all on that DNA, alright? Especially around family – they probably heard the same excuse last Diwali!
